name: NewYorker
text: From 2009, @ElizKolbert profiles James Hansen, known as the “father of global warming,” whose early climate models predicted most of what has happened to the climate since. https://t.co/YX1jjs2rwK

name: NewYorker
text: Edgar Allan Poe succinctly defined the anxiety Margaret Fuller engendered in her contemporaries when he divided humankind into three categories: men, women, and Fuller. https://t.co/Pll3zAnV8v

name: NewYorker
text: From 2016, @jelani9 writes about the origins and future of the Black Lives Matter movement. https://t.co/hpUR7jRVds

name: NewYorker
text: Dostoyevsky was a genius obsessed with social disintegration in his own time. "Crime and Punishment," encountered now, expresses what we are, and what we fear we might become. https://t.co/S8Qvprk4Dj

name: NewYorker
text: Elaine Stritch is magnetic in D. A. Pennebaker’s documentary about the recording of the original cast album for Stephen Sondheim’s “Company.” https://t.co/lTRIQqJhuK

name: NewYorker
text: Christopher St. John's “Top of the Heap” is a genre-twisting tale that couches psychological and political furies in bold imaginative flourishes, @tnyfrontrow writes. https://t.co/2IQb6BgQTz

name: NewYorker
text: Milton Glaser recognized the true job of graphic design. https://t.co/gOZaB7zx8x

name: NewYorker
text: The lynching of a man named Robert Edwards, in 1912, inaugurated a decades-long reign of terror in Forsyth County, Georgia. In “Blood at the Root,” Patrick Phillips delves into his home town’s violent history—and asks what we can do today. https://t.co/mrAowlHlGX

name: NewYorker
text: In 1970, a federal judge declared Arkansas’s prison system unconstitutional. Fifty years later, as the coronavirus spreads throughout the state’s prisons, inmates say that they are still being subjected to cruel and unusual punishment. https://t.co/nRT3f0MDgs

name: NewYorker
text: “There is no question in my mind that Larry helped change medicine in this country,” Dr. Anthony Fauci said, in 2002. “And he helped change it for the better.” https://t.co/FCB1XNplUR

name: NewYorker
text: CS50, Harvard’s introductory computer-science class, is one of the university’s most popular courses; it’s also the only one that students can watch live, in high definition, from their dorms. https://t.co/0go4GA2mjy

name: NewYorker
text: “A sudden hush fell on the crowd as Mr. Summers cleared his throat and looked at the list. ‘All ready?’ he called.” Listen to A. M. Homes read and discuss Shirley Jackson’s classic short story. https://t.co/aZOuv7Pnkb
